data.text: Dog Attacks when Cycle Touring Middle East

hi guys:) it's thomas from switzerland. i'm cycling towards east - the pamir is the final destination. since i've been in bosnia the dogs really scare me. every day i face a couple of those beasts and at least one is very agressive and tries to bite. i love to cycle alone, but now i would really appreciate to have some company for a couple of days to gain confidence in dealing with dogs. i've tried various things: staying calm, shouting at them, shaking a beer can filled with small stones, ... do you know someone who is currently cycling in this region? any idea how i can find someone to join will be be much appreciated üôÇ
Buy bear/paper spray. If the dog is too confident use it.
data.author: Dimit Ar

data.text: This has worked for me plus using a whistle like you‚Äôre a traffic policeman then direct them back like you‚Äôre police control.. info ; Why Dogs Chase Bikes The majority of dogs who chase bicycles are defending their territory. Other dogs are interested in chasing things or are curious about you. Remember, a small dog can cause just as bad a crash as a big dog. How Dogs Chase and Attack Bikes A dog will sometimes give chase from the yard, dashing across an open space and entering the road. Other dogs will stand in the road and block passage. Some bark, but not all. Dogs often attack from the rear, coming up from the side. A dog may wait for you to pass then give chase. You can sometimes use this to your advantage, a quick sprint might do the job of shaking the chasing dog. Road Bike Rider Rules for Dogs That Chase Bikes DO NOT KICK ‚Äì Kicking at the dog while riding has been called ‚Äúsuicide on a bike‚Äù. You can easily fall or become tangled with the dog. Consider a sprint, but carefully! You might be able to out sprint the dog when he‚Äôs not determined or just intimidating you. ‚ÄúYou can tell his intent by how hard he‚Äôs running and his expression. An easy gait with woofing and ears and tail up, no problem. A full-out sprint with ears back, tail down and teeth out, problem.‚Äù If you choose to sprint do so with caution. Erratic movements can lead to a crash. Guard your front wheel. ‚ÄúWhen a dog sees you coming, he might make a beeline for your bike, then attempt to turn up beside you. The danger here is that his poor little paws will skid on the pavement and he‚Äôll plow into your wheels. If he hits the front one, you‚Äôll crash.‚Äù Sprinting can put you out front, move forward faster than he expects, and give him a margin for error by steering away if the road and traffic permit. SCREAM! Try NO, OFF, STAY, BACK, loud bold words may surprise the dog and cause him/her to hesitate for just the second you need to take the advantage. You can also try raising a hand or waving your arm like you are throwing something. Again the priority is to maintain your seat on the bike. Spray water- Take out your water bottle. Just holding it may serve as a deterrent. ‚ÄúIf he does come near you, give him a faceful and a loud yell.‚Äù Again, watch your riding. Don‚Äôt crash. Halt pepper spray- clip this to your handlebar. Can be challenging to aim and affected by wind. Good to have around. Get off the bike- If other tactics are not working or seem dangerous get off the bike and put your bike between you and the dog. Swing the bike like a weapon if necessary, and start yelling for help. Call the cops. ‚ÄúIf you are attacked and bitten, report it to the county sheriff or other authority immediately. Include the location, a description of the dog and the owner‚Äôs name and address if you know them. Get medical attention without delay. If the dog was rabid, you are at risk of serious illness or even death. Demand proof of rabies vaccination or insist to authorities that the dog be quarantined.‚Äù Knowing in advance how to deal with dogs can help you reduce the chances of being bitten and crashing. A dog that just wants to give chase, but is not a real bite threat can still lead to a fatal crash. So think smart when you encounter a dog. Your life can depend on your actions. Stay alert

data.text: I've just ridden through Bosnia and other Balkans, now in Bulgaria and heading to Istanbul. I would have loved company at times, including for the reason of herd protection from dogs! I know you didn't ask for tips but there's one I've not seen anyone else post before. I was fortunate enough to have advance warning of a pack of dogs ahead on the road (I could hear them barking, it was night). I waited 5 minutes for the next car, flagged it down, pointed up the road and mimed snarling dogs. The driver understood straight away, put my bike in the back of his car and drove me past the burning trash dump where the wild dogs and pigs lived.

data.text: Dogs are scary. The mix og wild and household makes Them even more confused and aggressive. Usually the household dogs are the worst - they dont Seem to know how much they need to protect so they attack everything moving. We found that slowing All the way down or even stopping makes Them step back. Seems they understand you are a human and not to fight with. We drove for 8 months, tons of mad dogs (especially the kangals in Turkey) never got bitten when using the stopping raising our arms over our head method. üí™üèº
data.author: Jonas Schneeberg

data.text: Thank you! This is exactly my experience: The household dogs are the worst as they attack me straight out of nothing. What do you mean with the raising your arms over your head method?
data.author: Thomas Hodel

data.text: yes they er pure Devils breed! When full stop (usually with the most threatening dogs) raise one or both hands and wave at Them while just saying stop or singing or something like that. Try something (anything indicating you are human and can Sound and look like it) when they back off - slowly start pedalling away. Sometimes they get up for a second Chase so always look back just to check. If they start Chase again they Will be even more aggressive if you dont stop again and repeat the proces. But still 8 months zero bites. Sometimes the wild dogs saved us chasing away the household dogs üí™üèºüêï Try without sticks or Stones i think they are used to a lot of beating in general so that might not Work.

data.text: I know it sounds really hard and it is. But we found the best bet was to stop and threaten with rocks from the ground. Even if there aren‚Äôt rocks. Generally the dogs just like the run and stop really quick when you stop being something to chase. If not they almost all understand the universal language of I‚Äôve got a stone now. (Even if you don‚Äôt) I always got off the other side of the bike to the dog. But it does sound like youve got more aggressive dogs than we did

data.text: Don't let the fkers get you down. If you're going towards the Pamir, it's going to get worse with bigger stronger hungrier dogs...haha. My plan is to slow right down, find the leader and look really aggressive and shout 'F off' as loud as you can. I also carry a goat herder stick and a bottle of pepper spray. I've never had to use the stick nor the spray. You also have to hand in the spray at the Georgia/Azerbaijan border...which I think is still closed at the moment. Some people give wild dogs food but I think that this encourages them. I think they see it as a game. In 20 years on the road, I've never been seriously bitten.

data.author: Thomas Hodel

data.text: Nice bike, and a great adventure ahead. About dogs, yes, can be scary. I have learned to do the following things: 1. Be the Alpha, the bigger dog. But assertive rather than aggressive. 2. Point in the direction you want them to go - direct them away from you using arm motions and loud vocalizations. 3. Outrun them, careful not to excite them by your feet spinning rapidly. This choice is determined by how close they are to you when you notice them. 4. If necessary dismount keeping bike between you and them. 5. Sometimes I speak to them as a mother to a baby (I've tried everything). 6. Pick up, or pretend to pick up, a rock, or anything that could be perceived by them to be thrown at them. And then do so, either something real, or just something imaginary. 7. At times I've resorted to buying a squirt bottle and putting lemon juice in it keeping it handy in case I need to spray their eyes. This is something I don't like to do, and I think I've only done it once or twice. Some areas are rougher than others and the dogs are not amenable to being easily scared away. I feel badly about it, but I would feel worse getting bitten in the leg in a far off country. For the most part all my techniques have worked, and I've never been bitten, knock on wood! Good luck gaining the confidence to manage this daily hassle, and have a wonderful trip. Please keep us informed.
data.author: Paul Revier

data.text: Thank you so much :)
data.author: Thomas Hodel

data.text: Most dogs can be tamed by our own body language - which you can probably work on and take help of CBT professional as well. Some dogs can easily be tamed by offering food like biscuits etc. Also - I used to walk (have done no money, no phone 2100kms in India) with a medium stick seeing which they would not come very close, but keep barking only - which is fair given that you are entering their area and it's like a communication üòÅ

data.author: Leslie Carvery

data.text: I feel there are a lot of aggressive proposals here, like hitting with sticks, rocks and fluids. I met only a few dogs, on the road and was often amazed other people seemed to have met one dog after the other. I had the impression it had more to do with the impression the dogs made than with their sheer numbers. That said if you take a stick or rock, better be prepared to be able to hit them (hard and accurate) which I know , I am not good at myself. I‚Äôve seen them becoming more aggressive themselves when met with aggression. I feel more for the suggestion to be their alpha in a assertive way. Make assertive, but not angry eye-contact, and follow their actions carefully. Follow your intuition on when to escalate to make way or release the tension to calm them down, permanently evaluating the evolution. After such a confrontation with a dog chasing next to me on a fast downhill ride in the pouring rain in Georgia the dog ended up following and ‚Äòprotecting‚Äô us for more than 4 days. Another time a dog became aggressive when showing him a stone, so I decided instinctively to put it in my pocket again, saw him calming down, turned my back (in the meantime I had crossed him on the road) , while monitoring the sounds and looking casually over my shoulder to check he would stand ground and not attack. He let us pass. I think I would confirm attitude is key.
data.author: Maarten Van der Linden

data.text: Simply talk in a calm manner to them first up and mostly they‚Äôre fine‚Ä¶ a lot of foreigners carry sticks here in Thailand when they‚Äôre walking and instantly they‚Äôre met with aggression and other dogs come in aid of the dog who is getting a whopping with a stick..
data.author: Laurie Sams

data.text: Regular topic over the years, my considered view especially southern Balkan‚Äôs is use all the techniques you already have plus the humane ones above. But accept there‚Äôs a degree of luck & risk in all things! I had some difficult moments notably before and after Metsovo in northern Greece. Those mountain dogs are great looking after wild roaming sheep! They seem a ferocious cross between a polar bear and Rottweiler and when they‚Äôre without a herd, food or company and in numbers they‚Äôre dangerous.
data.author: James Prescott

data.text: Good luck, dogs are simply one of those things you will deal with on the road. Be kind, be careful, and be ready to defend your safety as a last resort. In Eastern Europe, especially in the mountainous regions they get really big and dangerous and anyone who hasn‚Äôt been attacked by a pack of spike collared herder dogs the size of small bears doesn‚Äôt know how terrifying such an encounter can be. I don‚Äôt think there is a one size fits all DO list as each dog, each region, and each situation is different and so is each cyclist. But there are some Don‚Äôts. Don‚Äôt try out alpha any creature if you can‚Äôt follow through unless it‚Äôs a life or death situation such as in the case of a male grizzly bear. Most dogs will interpret direct eye contact as a challenge. Likewise, a stick is a challenge to a regularly beaten stray dog, each situation is, well, situational. Don‚Äôt run, the only thing that runs in nature is food.
data.author: Nic Dekker

data.text: Did you try throwing dog biscuits? I had a friend who worked for the post office in Chicago. All the postmen were harassed by dogs and used spray and other things to scare them. She gave them dog treats and they all made friends with her and followed her on her route.
data.author: Stephen Mikesell

data.text: that works only with dogs which you encounter repeatedly.
data.author: Roland Okello

data.text: Probably true. Once I was riding through central Minnesota south from Minneapolis, and suddenly a dog looking like a very large wolf came running flat out across the field towards me. I thought, "I'm a gonner." But it turned out nobody was giving him attention at home and he just wanted to play. On the other hand I had a professor who was studying sheep herders in the Nepal Himalaya. One night he and a sheep herder wanted to visit another village so they set out. The sheep herder carried a large heavy pole which he would swing and set tumbling the mastiff sheep dogs that came at them from the darkness. That said, several sheep dogs that I met while trekking in Nepal, such as one we called Blackie and another we called Reddy (in Nepali) accompanied us, Reddy for several days before returning home. Of course I did not walk the high pastures at night when the dogs were on guard duty. Back in those innocent days, small children would also take up with us for several miles, engaging us with their curious and insightful thoughts. The author of the book "Four Against Everest" writing in 1962 spoke of how a small boy was sent 16 miles to fetch them after they'd come down from theor rather calamitous and illegal attempt to scale the north ridge of Mt. Everest.
data.author: Stephen Mikesell

data.text: I'm a friend of the brutal methods. Ignoring and stones. They usually try to bite the rear panniers, so staying cool is not to complicated and a stone coming from the bicycle teaches them to keep distance even when the stone don't touch any dog.
data.author: Roland Okello

data.text: YEAH... but if you're riding with someone else it will give them one hell of a headache before the end of the day. I know from experience.
data.author: Carol Maher

data.text: The good thing is that crossing USA i was using this only few times in Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi.
data.author: George Sea

data.text: a really loud whistle works for me.
data.author: Jenny Sun

data.text: If you are unable to buy pepper spray or mace, then carry an extra water bottle and fill it with vinegar or bleach (or any liquid that is a strong irritant to the eyes or open mouth). I have used this method in Latin America to good effect. One spray to the face and they retreat. Don't know how practical this would be with a pack of dogs, but 1 or 2 was not a problem.
data.author: Dave Wharton

data.text: Bleach? Does it not injure their eyes? I think it should just scare them away, not turn them into handicapped dogs.
data.author: Rita Biciclette

data.text: No, it doesn't. One would have to restrain the animal and expose it to a reasonably large amount to cause damage. The amount of exposure from a quick spray is just very unpleasant, and the body's natural defences flush irritants very quickly. The nature of aggessive dog attacks is such that the open mouth gets the bulk of anything sprayed anyway. I should state also that one is not just randomly causing grief for any dog that wanders close, but only when truly under attack. This has only occurred rarely for me and always when trekking village to village in rural Latin America. One has to weigh the risk, which for me would have been serious bites and possible rabies exposure...
data.author: Dave Wharton

data.text: why dont you put bleach in your eyes
data.author: Fabio Spiteri

data.text: Well, that is self evident to anyone; I place a higher value on my own health, than the temporary discomfort of a viscous dog, and dogs are generally intelligent enough to learn from the experience...
data.author: Dave Wharton

data.text: A High pitch whistle usually works for me.
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: Keep some bread in your pockets and throw it to them when they come. ;-)
data.author: Dan Mar

data.text: Use pepper....this is what people here in East Germany used against border dogs üêï before the wall was here...
data.author: Michael Nitsch

data.text: The most agressive dogs are usually not the barking Type. Down in south Am√©rica, in places where there are rocks at hand, they know how much damage one of those can do. Sometimes just pretend√≠ng to pick up a rock Will scare them off. If that doesn't work, aim for the Head. No mercy.
data.author: Juan Manuel Abago

data.text: I had an extendable metal cosh that I carried with me. If they come close to me I would give them a whack! Cheap can of deodorant spray at their eyes and strong smell puts them off.
data.author: Martin Gabriel

data.text: what happened after you hit them?
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: it give give them enough shock to get some more distance on them and usually stop them
data.author: Martin Gabriel

data.text: Get your self something to batter them with. Dnt be cycling empty handed,
data.author: Chris Kelly

data.text: Didn't read all the comments but for dogs I suggest a horn of this guy. It makes them run away. Good luck, and... you are super cute ü•∞
data.author: Brigitte Levesque

data.text: Many comments already. I didn't read them. Sorry if I repeat. I cycled from Germany down the balcans to the pamirs as well. If dogs came running I would stop. They usually then also stop. They love to run after who moves. Chasing isn't just fun but seems save tobthe dog. Someone who stops makes them not so cool out of the sudden. I also talk friendly to them. I believe a female voice filled with love does something but that's not an option for u or some I guess. I just love them so. In some countries locals throw rocks at them, so if one doesn't walk away and wants to keep coming when attempting to ride again, a bend over as if to grab a rock helps. I never worried, because they all stopped when I stopped. It feels wrong but look- everyone around walks and doesn't get barked at. The bike looks weird and it moves fast- I would bark and go for it too if it woke me up. üòÄStopping makes u look human and they are usually scary or good to dogs. I then rode with someone in Turkey and he squirted water at them, because he was sick of stopping. I saw that worked. Dogs get confused. I stuck to stopping. Also being 2 people didn't make it better. It is still a fast moving, funny object. Good luck!
data.author: Anna Hegenberg

data.text: Ps i absolutely love yellow. Looks fabulous!
data.author: Anna Hegenberg

data.text: I dealt with incessant, non-stop aggressive dogs in Mississippi, eventually I gathered a bunch of gravel and kept it handy to throw at them if they got too close. I turned one away after I smacked him in the nose with a little rock. I love dogs but it was dangerous and unbearable. I couldn't stop sometimes because I would have been bitten. I've also heard air horns work pretty well.
data.author: Jackson Graydon

data.text: Look for bicycle horn with tiger roars.
data.author: Victor Kang

data.text: Pepper spray
data.author: Gregg Pedder

data.text: So sad to hear this ,but all the straydogs are frightened and confused ... Hope you will get a companion and enjoy the ride with confidence very soon Cheers ü•Ç

data.text: In Romania I learned to slow down speed. And yes - bei aggressive. What also worked for me in Irland: an AirZound horn. Good luck!
data.author: Dirk Pr√ºter

data.text: Get a dog whistle also a nice long stick that you can put along the top tube. You can also try just stopping and assert authority over the dogs. I had the same issues in Ukraine turkey Bulgaria Romania Serbia hungry slovakia Best results for me are singing to them lol They cannot handle my voice or harmonica playing. But the harmonica did intrigue some of them
data.author: Hekta Burnz

data.text: Squirt them with your water bottle, it should work
data.author: Glen McGregor

data.text: Use water in case of emergency, don't run away, don't try to escape from them. It's better to walk slowly.
data.author: Gino Giano

data.text: Normally they are afraid of you approaching at a certain speed. Slow down and walk. They don't bark at pedestrians walking normally.
data.author: Martin Karlsson

data.text: hornet spray
data.author: Joe Dyer

data.text: Hate those aggressive dogs. We bought some pepper spray but happily have not to date had to use it. Have got off my bike a few times keeping the bike between me and the dogs. Having some atones handy helps as well. Good luck!
data.author: Michele Visser-Fitton

data.text: squeezable water bootle is effective to distract a dog
data.author: Joao Taborda
